title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | SB 1.17.16-17 | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 22-02-2023
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.text: Om Agyanati Miran Dhasya Gyananjan Shalakaya
Chaksharun Militam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
Nama Om Vishnu Padaya Krishna Preshtaya Bhutale
Shri Mate Bhakti Vedanta Swamin Nithinamine
Namaste Saraswate Deve Gauravani Pracharine
Nirvishesha Shunyavadi Pashchatya Deshatarine
Jaya Shri Krishna Chaitanya Prabhu Nithyananda
Shri Advaita Gadhadhara Shri Vasadi Gauravakta Vrinda
Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare
Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare
Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya Narayanam Namaskritya
Naram Chai Vanarottamam Deveem Saraswateem
Vyasam Tato Jaya Mudhirayet
In this session we are discussing from the 16th and the 17th verses
of the 17th chapter.
Chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam.
The title of the 17th chapter is Punishment and Reward of Kali.
How the Kali Yuga, the Kali Purusha, the personality who is the personification of this age, Kali,
Kali Yuga of this period, how he is dealt with by Parikshit Maharaj when Kali Yuga is
about to begin.
He is trying to enter Parikshit's kingdom when Dwapar Yuga is ending and the Kali Yuga
is going to begin and how he is dealt with that is very very instructive for all of us.
It gives us a clue why is it important for us.
It gives us a clue as to how we can protect ourselves against the evil influence of Kali,
this age, this time.
This atmosphere, the prevailing external conditions, the bad influence.
How can we protect ourselves provided of course pious people want to lead a life free from
sinful activities.
Want to lead a honest life.
A clean life.
A pious life.
Then how do they protect themselves against the evil influence?
That is the reason why this is being discussed here.
The 16th verse, Ragnyohi paramo dharma ha swadharma sthanu palanam shasato anyan yatha
shasram anapadi utpathan iha.
Let me read this.
Okay.

The meaning of this verse is, the supreme duty of the ruling king is to give all protection to law-abiding persons and to chastise those who stray from the ordinances of the scriptures in ordinary times when there is no emergency.
So, in the purport, Srila Prabhupada says,
In the scriptures, there is mention of apadharma or occupational duty at times of extraordinary happenings.
It is said that sometimes the great sage Vishwamitra had to live on the flesh of dogs in some extraordinary dangerous position.
Flesh-eating at a normal circumstances is completely forbidden.
Or if somebody,
somehow or the other, because they are very much desirous of enjoying eating some flesh, animal food, animal flesh,
then if they do so, then they are liable to be punished by the laws of God, the laws of nature, laws of karma.
But under extreme circumstances, when there is no food available except for flesh,
nothing,
something else is available, then one may eat flesh just to survive.
That is called apadharma, emergency time.
So, Srila Prabhupada says,
In cases of emergency, one may be allowed to live on the flesh of animals of all description.
But that does not mean that there should be regular slaughterhouses to feed the animal eaters.
And that this system should be,
encouraged by the state,
this is completely sinful.
When plenty of fruits, vegetables, grains, milk is available,
then why should people eat flesh?
Why should they kill animals for getting the flesh?
So, that is very, very sinful and severely,
punishable.
So, Srila Prabhupada says,
No one should try to live on flesh in ordinary time simply for the sake of the palate.
Palate means simply for satisfying the tongue.
Oh, I like to eat.
No.
Just because you like to eat, you cannot kill other animals.
As much as you have a desire to live,
you want to subsist in this particular,
in this particular present body.
Similarly, every living being has got the desire to live and should be allowed.
Should not be, there should be no unnecessary killing of even an ant.
Even a small plant, no unnecessary killing.
So, it is said here, Srila Prabhupada further,
If anyone does so,
it means they simply kill animals for the sake of satisfying their tongue.
The king or the executive head should punish him for gross enjoyment.
There are regular scriptural injunctions for different persons engaged in different occupational duties.
And one who follows them is called Swadharmastha
or faithful in one's prescribed duties.
Everybody has got a prescribed duty given in the scriptures.
Hmm.
In the Bhagavad Gita,
it is advised that one should not give up his occupational prescribed duties
even if they are not always flawless.
Swadharma,
what is prescribed for you according to your acquired nature.
According to your nature.
Hmm.
You have to perform a certain type of occupational duty to maintain yourself.
Such Swadharma might be violated in case of emergency,
but not in normal circumstances should you violate.
If one is forced by circumstances,
one may violate.
But they cannot be violated in ordinary times.
The state executive head is to see that such Swadharma is not changed by the follower,
whatever it may be,
and he should be given all protection.
The follower of the Swadharma should be given all protection by the king.
The violator is subject to punishment in terms of the Shastra.
Now what punishment who should get according to the particular violation.
Hmm.
Just like in ordinary law,
there are civil laws and criminal laws.
Civil laws is for some minor transgression,
transgression of some particular rule or law of the land.
Hmm.
Just like somebody is driving,
they are just exceeding the speed limit.
So that's not a very serious violation of the road rules or the law of the road driving,
driving laws.
So such a person may be just,
he may be just warned or he may be just given some small fine.
He has to pay.
That's all.
But somebody is driving rashly and killing another person
or bringing about severe accident,
severe damages,
then such a person is subject to criminal code of conduct.
Criminal laws are applicable in such cases.
So,
there is a difference depending on the kind of violation.
The duty of the king is to see that everyone strictly follows his occupational duty
as prescribed in the scriptures.
Shastras should be the basis.
Perfect.
They are perfect in all respects.
They are not made by some human beings with defects.
Shastras are given by
the Supreme Lord
and further elaborated upon by liberated souls,
saintly persons who are liberated personalities.
The 17th verse,
dharmavacha,
because Pariksit was speaking to dharma,
to the personality of religion.
So dharma is now responding to Pariksit Maharaj.
etad vaha pandavayanam
yuktam aartabhayam vachaha
yesam gunaganai krishno
dhautyadau bhagavan krutah
The meaning of this verse is
the personality of religion said,
he is replying to Pariksit Maharaj.
These words just spoken by you,
befit a person of the Pandava dynasty.
Captivated by the devotional qualities of the Pandavas,
even Lord Krishna,
the personality of Godhead,
performed duties as a messenger.
Something wonderful.
Dharma is telling about Pariksit Maharaj.
He is glorifying Pariksit Maharaj.
So in the Purpose, Srila Prabhupada says,
the assurances and challenges made by Maharaj Pariksit
are never exaggerations of his real power.
He is speaking,
I will punish anybody who violates.
I don't care even if that person who is violating is a
denizen of the heaven.
I don't care.
So these words
are befitting his actual position.
And they are not simply some exaggerations.
The Maharaja said that
even the denizens of heaven could not escape his stringent garment
if they are violators of religious principles.
He is a strict ruler.
And he has the power to
rule and enforce the law
of the scriptures,
the rules and regulations and laws of the scriptures,
even upon the devatas,
even upon superior beings.
He was not falsely proud
for a devotee of the Lord
is equally as powerful as the Lord
or sometimes more powerful by
the Lord's grace.
And any promise made by a devotee,
though it may be ordinarily very difficult to fulfill,
is properly executed by the grace of the Lord.
You see,
that's the position of a devotee.
Pariksit Maharaj is a pure devotee of the Lord.
So he has got extraordinary power.
Nobody else can have it.
Not even devatas can have as much power as Pariksit has.
Because Pariksit is a pure devotee.
So further, Srila Prabhupada says,
Pandavas, by their unalloyed devotional service,
unalloyed devotional service,
pure devotional service,
and full surrender to the Supreme Lord,
made it possible for the Lord to become
a chariot driver or sometimes their letter messenger.
See, Krishna, the Supreme Personality of Godhead,
worshipable by everyone,
including the devotees, everyone.
Everyone is a subservient to Krishna
and Krishna is supremely powerful,
unlimitedly powerful.
But that Krishna,
being captivated by the Pandavas' wonderful qualities,
devotional qualities,
he became their servant.
Voluntarily, he became their servant.
He became the chariot driver of Arjuna
in the battle of Kurukshetra.
He became the messenger of Yudhishthira.
He carried a message,
a peace message on behalf of Yudhishthira
to Duryodhana.
Toward the war,
the battle of Kurukshetra,
before the war was actually fought,
Yudhishthira wanted to avert this big world war.
So Krishna personally carried this message
from Yudhishthira to Duryodhana,
personally went.
So he was a letter messenger of Yudhishthira.
Such duties executed by the Lord for his devotee
are always very pleasing to the Lord
because the Lord wants to render service
to his unalloyed devotee
whose life has no other engagement
than to serve the Lord with full love and devotion.
The devotee wants to serve the Lord unconditionally.
The Lord wants to serve his devotees also
without any hesitation,
without any consideration that he is the Lord.
Maharaj Pariksit,
the grandson of Arjuna,
the celebrated friendly servitor of the Lord,
was a pure devotee of the Lord,
like his grandfather.
Who is his grandfather?
Arjuna.
Pariksit is the grandson of Arjuna.
Arjuna's son was Abhimanyu.
Abhimanyu's son was Pariksit.
So Pariksit was also a pure devotee like Arjuna.
Therefore the Lord was always with him
even from the time when he was helplessly
lying in the womb of his mother
and was attacked by the blazing Brahmastra weapon
of Ashwathama.
This is the history of Pariksit.
We discussed this earlier.
He was saved in his mother's womb
when he was an infant.
Not even an infant.
He was not even born.
Not even come out of the mother's womb.
He was protected by Krishna
because he was a devotee.
So when Pariksit makes an assurance,
it is always backed up
by the special protection
of the Supreme Lord Himself.
So the personality of religion, Dharma,
accepted this fact
and thanked the King
for his being true to his exalted position.
I will stop here.
Thank you very much.
Hare Krishna.
